item.title: Characters to Binary :O
item.dc:creator: @matzie matzie
item.description:
@matzie wrote:

[quote=“Devinhdl, post:12, topic:539642”][quote author=xx matty xx link=topic=658482.msg4404678#msg4404678 date=1391551581]
out of interest, what is this hilariously bad crypto for? you could make it a tiny bit harder to crack by converting chars to your own choice of bits instead of standard ascii
[/quote]
And that’s exactly what I did. I just used the actual binary output for ‘a’ as an example(not knowing about Integer.toBinary). But yes, I took the time and assigned my own binary value to each character/symbol. But since everyone suggested using Integer.toBinary, it does sound quite simpler and it could be a “go to” resort until I get this straightened out.

and thank you everyone for their two cents! thank you eyeownyew, I will play with that and see exaclty what it does, but from the looks of it it looks extremely helpful![/quote]

If you would like nothing more than a learning experience, write yourself a base converter first. One you can pass your own character map to - in order to encrpyt. Could make it operate in the same way as binary.
for example:
new BaseConverter(“a7”);
would use a’s and 7’s instead of 0’s and 1’s for converting.
the only issue is if you try this with a String, you would have to add a seperate implementtation for it. (Which you seem to have already written) at which case you can start learning to make multiple projects work together.

Read full topic

item.title: Characters to Binary :O
item.dc:creator: @eyeownyew Eyeownyew
item.description:
@eyeownyew wrote:

import java.util.Vector;

public class Converter {

	/**
	 * @param args
	 */
	public static void main(String[] args) {

		String example = "This is a test.";
		char[] exampleChars = example.toCharArray();
		String binaryString = "";
		for (char c : exampleChars) {
			String charBits = Integer.toBinaryString((int)c);
			while(charBits.length() < 8)
				charBits = "0"+charBits;
			binaryString += charBits;
		}
		System.out.println(binaryString);
		
		Vector<String> splitBits = new Vector<String>();
		for(int i = 0; i < binaryString.length(); i+=8) {
			splitBits.add(binaryString.substring(i, i+8));
		}
		String completeString = "";
		for(Object o : splitBits.toArray()) {
			String p = (String)o;
			completeString += (char)Integer.parseInt(p,2);
		}
		System.out.println(completeString);
	}

}

Far from efficient but it works perfectly

item.title: Characters to Binary :O
item.dc:creator: @ExtremeX-Scape Ryley
item.description:
@ExtremeX-Scape wrote:

[quote=“eyeownyew, post:8, topic:539642”]Oooooor[code=java]public class Converter {

public static void main(String[] args) {
	char c = 'a'; //Example character to convert
	String binary = Integer.toBinaryString((int)c); //(int)c is casting, changes character to an integer. Result: Binary string representation of the letter 'a'
	System.out.println(""+binary); //prints 1100001
	int character = Integer.parseInt(binary, 2); //Converts the binary string to an integer
	System.out.println(""+(char)character); //prints a
	System.out.println("Hex "+Integer.toHexString(Integer.parseInt(binary, 2))); //prints 61 (0x61, if you wanted to do hex for any reason)
}

}
[/code][/quote]

what if OP wanted a whole word, sentence or spaces?

Read full topic

item.title: Characters to Binary :O
item.dc:creator: @ExtremeX-Scape Ryley
item.description:
@ExtremeX-Scape wrote:

[quote=“xx matty xx, post:4, topic:539642”]Assuming your bits are simply stored in a string, use the substring method to pull out the 8-char segments.

http://docs.oracle.com/javase/6/docs/api/java/lang/String.html

Then just iterate through, incrementing 8 at a time.

(I was going to suggest being more efficient by converting each 8-bit segment to a char… lol)[/quote]

This^

here’s a shitty example:


import java.nio.charset.Charset;

public final class Converter
{

	public static void main( String[] args )
	{
		Converter converter = new Converter();
		System.out.println( converter.toBinary( "a b c" ) );
		System.out.println( converter.toString( converter.toBinary( "a b c" ) ) );
	}


	private final String toBinary( String string )
	{
		byte[] bytes = string.getBytes( Charset.forName( "UTF-8" ) );
		StringBuilder bldr = new StringBuilder( string.length() );
		for( byte value: bytes ) {
			bldr.append( String.format( "%8s", Integer.toBinaryString( value & 0xFF ) ).replace( ' ', '0' ) );
		}
		return bldr.toString();
	}


	private final String toString( String string )
	{
		byte[] buffer = new byte[ string.length() / 8 ];
		for( int index = 0, pos = 0; index < buffer.length; index ++ ) {
			String temp = string.substring( pos, pos + 8 );
			buffer[ index ] = ( byte )Integer.parseInt( temp, 2 );
			pos += 8;
		}
		return new String( buffer, Charset.forName( "ISO-8859-1" ) );
	}


	private Converter()
	{

	}

}

Read full topic

item.title: Characters to Binary :O
item.dc:creator: @pure2ownage Pure_
item.description:
@pure2ownage wrote:

[quote=“Devinhdl, post:5, topic:539642”][quote author=eyeownyew link=topic=658482.msg4404535#msg4404535 date=1391498034]
I understand the question but it’s not really what you’re looking for I believe. Unless you really want to mess with the binary yourself for learning purposes, you can just use
java.lang.Integer.toBinaryString(int i) for converting to binary
and
java.lang.Integer.parseInt(String s, int radix) for converting back to an integer

Just tested this, it works. I’ll let you see my copy if you’d like, it’s a lot simpler than you’d think.
[/quote]

Yes, that does seem pretty useful, but it will only convert integers into binary, I’m not too sure how to change that to characters, for different letters. Thanks for your help![/quote]

If I interpreted this correctly you don’t understand how to change the characters into integers? Characters are assigned a denary value and then given its binary equivalent (ie a is 97 and thus given 0110 0001, ASCII - ps UTF8 is backwards compatible with ASCII).

Casting a character to byte seems to give its correct denary equivalent, from there on you can just use a denary to binary convertor.

Likewise, casting a byte to character seems to give its correct character equivalent.

You just need to now, like matty said loop through the string and convert them one at a time.

Read full topic

@xx_matty_xx wrote:

Assuming your bits are simply stored in a string, use the substring method to pull out the 8-char segments.

http://docs.oracle.com/javase/6/docs/api/java/lang/String.html

Then just iterate through, incrementing 8 at a time.

(I was going to suggest being more efficient by converting each 8-bit segment to a char… lol)

item.title: Characters to Binary :O
item.dc:creator: @Devinhdl Devinhdl
item.description:
@Devinhdl wrote:

So I’m working on a little secret message phone application, not going through the details. One of the modes you can set the secret message application to, is kinda like text to binary.

Let’s start off with an example. If one was to type the letter ‘a’, it would spit out, “01100001”. That’s not a problem I’m facing. I’m facing a problem where I have to convert it back to the letter ‘a’. The question being, How do I make a loop cycle through eight characters(in this case ones and zeros), and store it into which every data type is applicable, and will easily be read by my switch statement.

example switch statement:

StringBuffer s = new StringBuffer(mes.length()); switch (example) { case 01100001: s.append("a"); break; }

“mes” being the secret message.

No one has to spoon feed me, just anything will help!
Thank you in advance.

Read full topic
